bibl.title: Letter from George Parker to Henry Rose Carter, October 29, 1921

div1.p: Parker reports on a malaria survey in Texas. He describes campaign details. All towns show good results.

div1.head: Letter from George Parker to Henry Rose Carter, October 29, 1921
div1.opener:
Malaria
Texas
THE STATE OF TEXAS
MANTON M. CARRICK, M. D., PRESIDENT
AND STATE HEALTH OFFICER
TEXAS
STATE BOARD OF HEALTH
AUSTIN. TEXAS
Jacksonville, Texas,
October 29, 1921.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
Asst. Surgeon General, U.S.P.H.S.,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:-
div1.p:
I know you will be interested to learn of a malaria
survey that is now being made in Cherokee County, Texas. I am enclosing
my campaign map that you might see the progress to date, etc. The cam-
paign was started on Sept. 15th., right after school opened. It is ex-
pected to visit each of the 71 school districts where a lecture is de-
livered, in the language of those present, on how malaria is contracted,
what it is, and what everyone can do to prevent it or keep well of it.
Literature of various kinds is distributed among the school children,
pertaining to malaria fever. A thick blood smear is taken of about 33
per cent of all scholastics, and examined in the laboratory, provided for
this purpose, for the malaria parasite. The County Red Cross Chapter
appropriated $1,000.00 to conduct this survey, which goes toward paying
the salary of a medical officer and supplies.

All records are being kept by age, sex, color, number lectured, number of
pieces of literature distributed, the topographical features of each district
and its percentages, etc. Any information desired can be compiled from the
records.

The Cotton Belt Ry. passes through the entire length of this
county and Mr. Van Hovenberg is rendering assistance in ever way possible to
help to success.

In the percentages given the histories may seem to be a little out of
proportion in relation to the positive findings, but I feel that that
can readily be accounted for. To be sure that we get only a malarial
history nothing is accepted but a typical chill history. Amongst the
smaller children this is likely to be given inaccurate but care is taken
that it is in every way a malaria history. Then with the older people
we have the chill tonic users, who at this time of year are using plenty
of the tonic and do during the malaria season of each year; some also
use quinine in a measure and do not chill. However, in every case but
two so far, the young ring form of Schizont has been found in the
positive cases that gave no history. Some few that have been followed
up have even chilled for the first time after our findings, so we get
some new cases with negative histories.

What all this work will lead to I do not know. Prospects
for going on with cooperative malaria work seem small for this State
just now. The Legislature made no appropriation to enable the State
Board to expand or carry the entire burden. All of this, and other
things too, make my continuing here very uncertain. However, my plan
for this county's work is to provide all funds locally. I have in mind
a $250,000.00 program, and so far it has been well received but could
not be put over without a great deal of additional work. A yearly tax
does not appeal to me as the logical way to start and continue a program
of this nature, and as taxes are already considered high, and business
depressed, such a measure could hardly be put across. Any way if it was
there would always be the possibility of its being discontinued. So the
$250,000.00 would be in a form of a bond issue, 30 or 40 years, and to
conduct a five to ten years program. This would result in an easy tax
and in advance could be shown how it would pay itself off long before the
bonds had to be redeemed.

It is hoped that after the initial examination survey is
made to revisit the districts and hold conferences with the parents who,
by that time, will have disposed of their crops and have the time to devote
to the issue. On this survey we will have the result of malaria infection
in each district and be able to put forth convincing arguments. The rural
cooperation has been excellent, and every school superintendent and civic
organization in the county are ready to help get rid of malaria.

We are trying to induce each school to establish and
maintain a Gambusia hatchery for their district, and while there are a
number of ponds being prepared I can not say how successful it will be.

The unit work has moved along very well this year, all towns
showing good results and bound to continue the work through years to follow.
I hope you will be at the Hot Springs conference next month.
